docs.snippet: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 6--The Chilean military Government conceded today that official passports might have been issued to two men being sought for questioning in the killing of former For-eign Minister Orlando Letelier in Washington.
docs.lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 6--The Chilean military Government conceded today that official passports might have been issued to two men being sought for questioning in the killing of former For-eign Minister Orlando Letelier in Washington.
docs.abstract: Govt concedes that official passports might have been issued to Romeral Jara and Rose; Pinochet asks Sup Ct to appt special judge to investigate and orders Foreign Min to cooperate; State Dept forwards to Santiago request from Fed Dist Ct for DC that men, identified as Juan Williams Rose and Alejandro Romeral Jara be questioned on Letelier's killing; identity of men is major issue because names on official Chilean passports are presumed false; man named Rose has been identified by newspaper El Mercurio as Michael Vernon Townley, allegedly N Amer who was living in Chile during Allende regime and was accused by press in '73 of being CIA agent; man named Romeral is identified by newspaper La Segunda as Rafael Undurraga Cruzat, former naval officer and electronics expert working as production mgr for local elec co; both are active members of right-wing extremist orgn Patria y Libertad (M)

headline.main: CHILE ORDERS INQUIRY IN THE LETELIER CASE; Government Concedes Two Sought by U.S. May Have Traveled on Official Passports Meeting With Cubans Reported Object of Senate Inquiry U.N. Group Accuses Chile

byline.original: By JUAN de ONIS Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 15 (Reuters)-- The Carter Administration wants to curb the recent sharp growth in lending to developing countries by the World Bank and other international financial institutions, according to a new Treasury Department report.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 15 (Reuters)-- The Carter Administration wants to curb the recent sharp growth in lending to developing countries by the World Bank and other international financial institutions, according to a new Treasury Department report.
docs.abstract: New Treas Dept rept indicates Carter Adm wants to curb recent sharp growth in lending to developing countries by World Bank (M)

docs.snippet: DR. MARK GERARD, the famous veterinarian, is scheduled to appear in Nassau County Court this morning for arraignment on charges related to those initially lodged against him. Gerard, you  will recall, is the central figure in the alleged switch of...
docs.lead_paragraph: DR. MARK GERARD, the famous veterinarian, is scheduled to appear in Nassau County Court this morning for arraignment on charges related to those initially lodged against him. Gerard, you will recall, is the central figure in the alleged switch of two horses, one a plugger and the other a champion, that resulted in a $77,920 betting coup at Belmont last Sept. 23.
docs.abstract: Peter Maas article examines role of trainer Jack Morgan in so-called 'Sting' affair involving Dr Mark Gerard; illus (M)

docs.snippet: MINEOLA, L.I., March 27--Dr. Mark J. Gerard, the Long Island veterinarian who is under indictment for switching race horses in a betting court last fall, pleaded not guilty today to two additional charges of bribing a witness and tampering with a...
docs.lead_paragraph: MINEOLA, L.I., March 27--Dr. Mark J. Gerard, the Long Island veterinarian who is under indictment for switching race horses in a betting court last fall, pleaded not guilty today to two additional charges of bribing a witness and tampering with a witness.
docs.abstract: Dr Gerard, under indictment for switching race horses, pleads not guilty, Mineola, NY, to additional charges of bribing witness and tampering with witness; witness is identified as Christa Mancuso (M)

headline.main: 2 Charges Added in Gerard Case; Insurance Payment Made

docs.snippet: MEXICO CITY, April 1--A bitter struggle has erupted between liberal and conservative sectors of Latin America's Roman Catholic Church over the political strategy that the continent's bishops should follow over the next 10 years.
docs.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY, April 1--A bitter struggle has erupted between liberal and conservative sectors of Latin America's Roman Catholic Church over the political strategy that the continent's bishops should follow over the next 10 years.
docs.abstract: Article on bitter struggle between liberal and conservative sectors of Latin Amer's RC Ch over pol strategy that continent's bishops should follow over next 10 yrs; focal point of dispute is 3d Latin Amer bishops' conf, planned for Mex city of Puebla in Oct, at which ch will either endorse or modify radical pol recommendations of last such conf, held in Colombia in '68 (L)

headline.main: Catholic Bishops in Latin America Wage Bitter Struggle Over Church's Leftist Trend; Church Identified With Wealthy Preparatory Document Causes Uproar Dissension in the Church Attacks on Clergy 'Social Doctrine' Revived 'The Infinite Suffering of Our People'

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES April 19--The approval by the United States Senate yesterday of the treaty ceding the Panama Canal to Panama in 1999 was received more with relief than enthusiasm in most of Latin America.
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES April 19--The approval by the United States Senate yesterday of the treaty ceding the Panama Canal to Panama in 1999 was received more with relief than enthusiasm in most of Latin America.
docs.abstract: Latin Amer govts are relieved by Sen action on treaties; most govts feared impasse would lead to violence in Panama and confrontation with US in which Latin Amer would have had to take sides; Venezuelan Pres Andres Perez and Colombian Pres Lopez Michelsen comment (M)

headline.main: LATINS ARE RELIEVED AT CANAL TREATIES; Senate's Approval Is Viewed as Ending Threat of Violence That Might Have Split Hemisphere Carter's Problems Emphasized

docs.snippet: DENVER, April 24--Frank T. Cary, chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, reported today that I.B.M. now has the largest backlog of orders in its history and expects to add 10,000 people to its manufacturing divisions.
docs.lead_paragraph: DENVER, April 24--Frank T. Cary, chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, reported today that I.B.M. now has the largest backlog of orders in its history and expects to add 10,000 people to its manufacturing divisions.
docs.abstract: Cary repts co now has largest backlog of orders in its history and expects to add 10,000 people to mfg divs, annual meeting; criticizes Justice Dept's 9-yr-old antitrust suit against co; denies co has been prolonging case; proposal, sponsored by coalition of ch groups, asking that co investigate use of co computers in totalitarian Latin Amer countries to see if they are being used to carry out repressive policies, gains stockholder support (S)

headline.main: I.B.M. SAYS BACKLOG IS AT RECORD LEVEL; Company, Using Plants on 3 Shifts, Is Expanding Output Capacity, Stockholders Are Informed Charge Rebutted Policies Requested
